Issues.Title: Positive and Negative Values from Binary Classification
Issues.Body: Is there any way to get a list of positive vs. negative values from a model if using binary classification? Also, a follow-up question. When getting a prediction on a binary classification can any information be passed as to why the engine selected positive vs. negative?

Issues.Title: Make IChannel `.Done` Done
Issues.Body:
One of the most fun design decisions w.r.t. `IChannel` is that it should have a `.Done()` method, analogous perhaps to things we see in databases like commits and whatnot. The purpose is to indicate that the channel actually reached the end of the code block successfully, in the way that the code writer thought it would, and thus distinguish between the case where the channel was disposed because we reached the end vs. the channel was disposed for some other reason. (Because, I guess, the alternative, an exception being thrown and interrupting the flow of code, wasn't conspicuous enough of a signal.)

That's fine if a little redundant. However, this *does* incur a cost to code. Consider for example this code here:

https://github.com/dotnet/machinelearning/blob/a3b67d393714ebeb873a41af82cd22ea7311e44c/src/Microsoft.ML.Core/Data/IHostEnvironment.cs#L229-L235

Now, it *could* have been written like this:

```csharp
using (var ch = host.Start(channelName))
    return func(ch);
```

But we can't, because, of course, we need to make sure we call `ch.Done()`, which means we have to store the return value somewhere else, etc. etc.

By itself that isn't that bad, except we use channels literally everywhere. So we see this pattern repeated over, and over, and over again. I've done this so often I even have a standard variable name I personally use to work around this thing, `retval`.

Yet, despite being used everywhere in the codebase, over the years I can count the number of times that check has been useful on exactly zero of my hands. In fact it is so useless that we never actually bothered to consider it an error condition, since there are far more examples of people forgetting to do that than examples where it actually signaled a problem -- refer to the example above, the "mistake" is far more obvious than the correct actually implemented pattern -- and again, the alternative, an exception being thrown, was far more obvious anyway. So it just writes an easily ignored warning to the *trace* stream if it's detected (which is a logging layer people by default cannot visibly access anyway).

Maybe we ought to get rid of it, just rely on the fact that the channel is being disposed (which contrary to this `Done` thing does convey very useful information), and simplify a bunch of code.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Make IChannel `.Done` Done" (#803)

Issues.Title: Address additional comments on the TensorFlowTransform PR
Issues.Body:
Post merge, there are some additional comments that were added to the TensorFlowTransform PR #704 . 
Also, during the bug bash there was a request to update the documentation in a few places. 

Creating an issue to address these asks.  

Listing down the issues being addressed:

1.  Check for number of rows in unit test `TensorFlowTransformCifar` . [comment](https://github.com/dotnet/machinelearning/pull/704#discussion_r214075997)

2.  Fix `TensorFlowTransformCifarLearningPipelineTest` test. [comment](https://github.com/dotnet/machinelearning/pull/704#discussion_r214075714)

3. Update the TensorFlowTransform documentation to include a pointer to the nugets required for running the TensorFlowTransform.

Issues.Title: Add Initialize() method to TensorFlow and ImageAnalytics
Issues.Body:
Fixes #794 .
In order to use the pipeline API, users will be required to call the Initialize() method in order to load the assemblies that contain the relevant entry points.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Add Initialize() method to TensorFlow and ImageAnalytics" (#795)

Issues.Title: ImageAnalytics entry points are not loaded when using the Microsoft.ML.ImageAnalytics nuget
Issues.Body: The issue is that the ModuleCatalog loads only entry points that are in assemblies used directly in the code. When using the pipeline API we instantiate objects that are defined in the Microsoft.ML assembly, so the assembly where the actual entry points are located does not get loaded.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ImageAnalytics entry points are not loaded when using the Microsoft.ML.ImageAnalytics nuget" (#794)

- **.NET Version (eg., dotnet --info)**: latest master branch

[8/30/2018 5:06:37 PM Informational] [xUnit.net 00:00:12.4333372] D:\mldotnet0823\machinelearning\src\Microsoft.ML.ImageAnalytics\ImageLoaderTransform.cs(92,0): at Microsoft.ML.Runtime.ImageAnalytics.ImageLoaderTransform..ctor(IHost host, ModelLoadContext ctx, IDataView input)
[8/30/2018 5:06:37 PM Informational] [xUnit.net 00:00:12.4334287] D:\mldotnet0823\machinelearning\src\Microsoft.ML.ImageAnalytics\ImageLoaderTransform.cs(110,0): at Microsoft.ML.Runtime.ImageAnalytics.ImageLoaderTransform.<>c__DisplayClass11_0.b__0(IChannel ch)

[8/30/2018 5:06:37 PM Informational] [xUnit.net 00:00:12.4349911] Output:
[8/30/2018 5:06:37 PM Informational] [xUnit.net 00:00:12.4350922] Test EntryPointExecGraphCommand: aborted: passed
[8/30/2018 5:06:37 PM Informational] [xUnit.net 00:00:12.4543727] Finished: Microsoft.ML.Core.Tests

Issues.Title: Add a C# API to ML.NET to extract input/output layers information from DNN models
Issues.Body:
We need to add functionality to ML.NET to be able to extract information about the names/types/sizes of the input and output layers in a DNN model (this applies to both TensorFlow and ONNX models).

One possible way to do this is to add to ML.NET an auxiliary console application that can list that information given a model. Another option is to add a utility method that returns this information as a schema object that can be explored by the user.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add a C# API to ML.NET to extract input/output layers information from DNN models" (#791)

Issues.Title: Add Date Transform/Vectorizers
Issues.Body:
It naturally makes sense to be able to take a date column and break it into the common sub components used in data analysis. As a very common workflow, it makes sense to build a vectorizer that does this internally effectively adding columns to the dataset from a single source date column which can then be Concatenator to the features.

I was thinking perhaps a vectorizer that takes a flags enum of various types of date transform (e.g. Day, Month, Year, Day of Week, Day of Year, Quarter, ISO Week of Year, etc). Obviously there are many ways to slice a date so maybe ultimately the best option is a builtin user defined formula transform which can solve this but Dates are a very common workflow as lots of real world data is actually time series.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add Date Transform/Vectorizers" (#789)

Issues.Title: Updates to Unit Test cases for the TensorFlowTransform
Issues.Body:
Fixes #779 

(1) address the additional comments on the original TensorFlowTransform [PR](https://github.com/dotnet/machinelearning/pull/704)

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Make perf results table of CpuMath hardware intrinsics more informative" (#788)

Issues.Title: Differences in FastTreeBinaryClassifier between versions
Issues.Body:
In the Sentiment Analysis sample, when running 0.3.0 or  0.4.0 you get different results.

**Both results in the console are positive** for 0.4.0. The **first result should be negative** if it is supposed to be the same as 0.3.0, which I'd assume it would.

https://github.com/dotnet/docs/issues/7024
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Differences in FastTreeBinaryClassifier between versions" (#787)

Issues.Title: Porting the tests for Different Sweepers
Issues.Body:
Currently there are just tests for UniformRandomSweeer And RandomGridSweeper.

There are no tests for DeterministicSweeper,  SimpleSweeper,  SmacSweeper and NelderMeadSweeper. This will increase code coverage and will help to catch any current or future bugs in these Sweeper classes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Porting the tests for Different Sweepers" (#786)

Issues.Title: Documentation fixes for .5 release
Issues.Body:
List of api docs needing revision:
* [ ] - [LearningPipeline](https://review.docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.ml.learningpipeline?view=ml-dotnet&branch=smoke-test-preview)
* [ ] - [OnnxConverter.Convert(PredictionModel) Method](https://review.docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.ml.models.onnxconverter.convert?view=ml-dotnet&branch=smoke-test-preview#Microsoft_ML_Models_OnnxConverter_Convert_Microsoft_ML_PredictionModel_)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Documentation fixes for .5 release" (#785)

Issues.Title: Using TensorFlowTransform with pre-trained models that are not frozen.
Issues.Body:
Currently the TensorFlowTransform works with frozen TensorFlow models as input.

We need to investigate what it takes to get it to work with models that are not frozen.
This will also help if in the future we want to do transfer learning via fine-tuning of pre-trained models.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Using TensorFlowTransform with pre-trained models that are not frozen." (#784)

Issues.Title: Bump the master branch to 0.6
Issues.Body: Setting the master to 0.6
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Bump the master branch to 0.6" (#782)

Issues.Title: Delete dead code related to AVX
Issues.Body:
Some of the original code relating to AVX and SSE is dead and can be deleted including

* all of avx.cpp and avx.cs
* functions in thunk.cs that exposed avx.cpp functions, eg MatMulDX

I checked in TLC as well and the above were only used by code in NeuralNetworks/*, which will not migrate to ML.NET.

I also notice some functions in sse.cs seem dead eg MeanOfSrc
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Delete dead code related to AVX" (#780)
